At times, when a small group of men entrusted with the general management of the work have, in the name of the General Conference, sought to carry out unwise plans to restrict God's work, I have said that I could no longer regard the voice of the General Conference, represented by these few men, as the voice of God. But this is not saying that the decisions 
                                                                           56
of a General Conference composed of an assembly of duly appointed, representative men from all parts of the field should not be respected.
